chapter.title: Server administration
chapter.para: The first step in &eyedb; administration adresses the server administration: as all existing database management systems, &eyedb; adopts a client/server architecture to provide databases integrity and concurrent accesses. Every database operation requires that a server is up and running; this chapter explains how to start and stop the server, get its status and manage its configuration.

section.title: The &eyedbctl; command
section.para: The &eyedb; server is started, stopped and examined using the &eyedbctl; command. This command is installed in /usr/sbin for standard &eyedb; installations.

The &eyedbctl; command has the following syntax:
&eyedbctl;commandoptions
where command is one of start, stop or status.

The following options are the most usefull:
--listen=
hostname: port
unix socket name
,
specifies the port the server is listening on. This port can be either a TCP port, specified by a hostname (defaults to "localhost") and a TCP port number, or a Unix socket, specified by a file name.
--access-file=file specifies the server access file for network configuration (see )
--server-conf=file specifies the server configuration file (see )
--nod no daemon mode, do not close file descriptors 0, 1 band 2

section.title: Starting &eyedb; server
section.para:
The &eyedb; server is started using the following command:
&eyedbctl;startoptions

example.title: &eyedbctl; start
example.screen: eyedbctl start Starting EyeDB Server Version V2.8.8 Compiled Feb 14 2009 00:16:45 Architecture i686-pc-linux-gnu Program Pid 19433

section.para:
By default, the &eyedb; server listens to incoming client connections on 2 ports:
a TCP/IP socket bound to port 6240
a Unix socket bound to file name /var/lib/eyedb/pipes/eyedbd for standard installation, or PREFIX/var/lib/eyedb/pipes/eyedbd where PREFIX is the installation prefix that has been set during configuration

example.title: &eyedbctl; start with --listen option
example.screen: eyedbctl start --listen=localhost:10000,/var/tmp/eyedb-socket Starting EyeDB Server Version V2.8.8 Compiled Feb 14 2009 00:16:45 Architecture i686-pc-linux-gnu Program Pid 19560

section.title: Stopping &eyedb; server
section.para:
The &eyedb; server is stopped using the following command:
&eyedbctl;stopoptions

example.title: &eyedbctl; stop
example.screen: eyedbctl stop Killing EyeDB Server Pid 19433

section.para: If the server was started with the --listen option to set the listening port, the same option must be passed to eyedbctl when stopping the server.

example.title: &eyedbctl; stop with --listen option
example.screen: eyedbctl stop No EyeDB Server is running on localhost:6240 eyedbctl stop --listen=localhost:10000,/var/tmp/eyedb-socket Killing EyeDB Server Pid 19560

section.title: Getting &eyedb; server status
section.para:
The &eyedb; server status can be obtained using the following command:
&eyedbctl;statusoptions
This command will print on its standard output informations about the &eyedb; server currently running: server PID and user, version, listening ports and list of connected clients.

example.title: &eyedbctl; status
example.screen:
eyedbctl status
EyeDB Server running since Thu Mar 5 16:08:45 2009
Version V2.8.8 Date Feb 14 2009 00:16:45 Architecture i686-pc-linux-gnu Program Pid 19433 Running Under francois
Listening on localhost:6240 localhost:/home/francois/projects/eyedb/install/var/lib/eyedb/pipes/eyedbd Datafile Directory /home/francois/projects/eyedb/install/var/lib/eyedb/db
No Clients connected.

section.para: Same as for stopping server, if the server was started with the --listen option to set the listening port, the same option must be passed to eyedbctl when getting server status.

example.title: &eyedbctl; status with --listen option
example.screen:
eyedbctl status --listen=localhost:10000,/var/tmp/eyedb-socket EyeDB Server running since Thu Mar 5 16:09:07 2009
Version V2.8.8 Date Feb 14 2009 00:16:45 Architecture i686-pc-linux-gnu Program Pid 19560 Running Under francois
Listening on localhost:10000 localhost:/var/tmp/eyedb-socket Datafile Directory /home/francois/projects/eyedb/install/var/lib/eyedb/db
No Clients connected.

section.para: If clients are connected, the server status will show the list of connected clients, giving for each client a list of open databases.

example.title: &eyedbctl; status with connected clients

section.title: Configuring &eyedb; server logging
section.para: The &eyedb; server can log its activities with a fine grain control over what is logged (client connections, transactions, index...). This logging can be done into a file or into a special file such as /dev/stderr.

The following options of &eyedbctl; are used to control server logging:
--logdev=logfile
specifies output log file (can be either a plain file, or a special file like /dev/stderr
--logmask=mask
specifies log mask (see for log mask values)
--logdate=onoff
controls display of date in output log
--logtimer=onoff
controls display of time in output log
--logpid=onoff
controls display of process pid in output log
--logprog=onoff
controls display of program name in output log

Log mask is either an hexadecimal number or a combination of symbols prefixed by + (to enable the corresponding log) or - (to disable the corresponding log). The list of allowed symbols can be obtained by running eyedbctl start --logmask=help. For instance, specifying --logmask=+server+connection will log all server and connection events.
shows an example of launching &eyedb; server with logging enabled, running an &eyedb; command and examining the log file (here /var/tmp/eyedbd.log) with the tail.
